Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Investigation of Nucleate Boiling Phenomena using Hierarchically Porous Constructs with Well-Defined Microstructure

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Investigation of Nucleate Boiling Phenomena using Hierarchically Porous Constructs with Well-Defined Microstructure

Phase change heat transfer has been a topic of significant scientific and technological interest as it can serve as an efficient cooling method for high heat flux applications. Nucleate boiling is one of the most effective heat transfer mode, which is governed by a complex process of bubble growth on, and departure from, heating surfaces. Textured surfaces and porous materials have been commonly used to enhance the surface area for heat transfer and the bubble nucleation kinetics. To more effectively utilize nucleate boiling in technological practice, it is essential to better understand the dynamics of bubble nucleation and departure on textured surfaces and porous materials. Such studies will provide multi-disciplinary training opportunities that merge thermal transport physics, nanoengineering, and materials science. The insights gained from such a study would enable advances in a wide range of technologies in which thermal management is critical, including high-power-density electronic devices, data servers, and electronic warfare.

The proposed study will seek to design hierarchically porous metallic constructs to engineer nucleate boiling heat transfer. To this end, this study will utilize a new class of three-dimensional (3D) hierarchically porous metallic structures using a recently developed soft matter templating method with independent control over two scales of pore sizes (from nano- to tens of micrometers). The materials system with well-defined porous structure will help to investigate how hierarchical pore distribution affects bubble size, frequency and nucleate boiling phenomena. Simultaneous parametric computational studies and preliminary results from boiling and wetting tests will help to advance fundamental understandings of thermal transport mechanism through porous media.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As the performance density of high-power electronic systems is severely limited by their cooling systems, their need for sophisticated cooling mechanisms increases concomitantly. Two-phase cooling systems integrating nanoengineered features have the potential to dissipate large heat fluxes through their structures and surface characteristics by providing structural impact to boiling regimes. To realize their potential improvements in boiling heat transfer performance, we proposed to design and study well-controlled hierarchically porous metallic constructs with the aim of engineering nucleate boiling phenomena. For this, we demonstrated porous metallic structures with a precise control via template-assisted method. The fabrication control includes the control of liquid pathway formation (i.e., interconnecting pores), tortuosity, and pore size of microstructures as well as nanoscale surface roughness, which impacts liquid feeding through well-controlled microstructures. Combined parametric computational and experimental study helped us to understand the effects of structural details and surface chemistry on thermofluidic performances by tracking the liquid-vapor interfaces within fabricated microstructures. Throughout this study, we have measured wetting and droplet infiltration behaviors using different combinations of microporous and nanoporous structures in order to understand the permeability through the designed pore geometry through optical observation and environmental scanning electron microscopy measurement. In addition, experimental boiling measurements for various pore sizes and thicknesses are followed by using thermofluidic optical setup. The combined measurements also showed that wicking through both the out-of-plane and in-plane directions of porous structures governs corresponding boiling phenomena. The proposed work resulted in research presentations at international conferences (including a best presentation award) and several journal publications. It should be noted that there two manuscripts in preparation for journal publication as well. Understanding about bubble dynamics is proposed help the design of heat sinks to push the limits of two-phase thermal transport and facilitate high-performance cooling. The proposed work has also contributed to engineering education by offering mentorship to undergraduate or high schoolers and by participating in multiple events to educate female or minority students at UC Irvine. 

 


Last Modified: 02/24/2020
Modified by: Yoonjin Won
